We need those as well. We don't like to admit that we have a working class and we have been conditioned to believe that we don't exist with expanded definitions of "Middle Class-ism" and other euphemisms. Labor is the political "N" word in America.  Mustn't say that lest someone think we are one. I am Labor-- working class!  DO YOU HEAR ME USA? >>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<< Sounds like around 40 years ago, you'd be the type beating peoples heads in for being Capitalists for Pol Pot's  Khmer Rouge, 50 years ago for Mao with the Cultural  Revolution for being an intellectual, and 75 years ago for Stalin for those being a Wrecker, going against the will of the Party. Left could always could find thugs willing to hurt any member of the 'Bourgeois', no shortage of haters Seems that the thugs are still around, hating anyone who had done better. >>> END COMMENT <<< ### Targets ### •Police •Barack Obama •Capitalism •Vegetarians / Vegans •Islam •Social welfare •Journalists •The government •Ukraine •America / USA •Sport •Israel •Movies •Russia •Christianity •Jobs are (available | good) •Terrorism •Healthcare •Elites •Nancy Pelosi •Jews •Democrats •Kamala Harris •Liberals •White people •Donald Trump •Christians •Climate change is (real | a problem) •Sarah Palin •Immigration / immigrants •Politicians •Food •Covid •Fossil fuels •Hillary Clinton •Music •Republicans (GOP) •Military •Joe Biden •Economy is good •Abortion •Feminism •Black people •Fascism / Nazism •Muslims •Diversity •Vaccines •Taxes are (good | fair) •Media •Conservatives •Drugs •Gay / LGTBQ+ •Social media •Progressives •Hobbies •Scientists •Woke •Crime •Socialism / Communism •China ### Task Description ### For each target, determine the stance in the comment: - If the stance is in favor of the target or agrees with the target, write FAVOR - If the stance is against the target or disagrees with the target, write AGAINST - If the stance is ambiguous, write NONE - If the comment is not related to the target, write NOT RELATED ### KEY CLAIM ### - Extract the fundamental assertion or belief that form the basis of the commenter's stance - The key claim should be expressed impersonalizing the user in the form of "I agree with the following: ". - If no stance is expressed (NOT RELATED, NONE) then leave the explanation field empty. ### Output Format: ### You must output only JSON format: { "results": [ { "target": "", "stance": "", "stance_type": "", "explanation": " if stance in FAVOR/AGAINST" }, // Repeat for each target ] } ONLY return the JSON object itself.

LePage (R) won against gun control candidate Michael Michaud (D). In Senate races, gun control Senator Mark Udall (D-CO) was defeated by NRA-endorsed Cory Gardner (R) and gun control Senator Kay Hagan (D-NC) was defeated by NRA-endorsed Thom Tillis (R). In Kansas, NRA-endorsed Senator Pat Roberts (R) won. In Georgia, NRA-endorsed Senatorial candidate David Perdue (R) won. In Arkansas, NRA-endorsed Tom Cotton (R) won. And in West Virginia, NRA-endorsed Shelley Moore Capito(R) won, marking the first time that state has sent a Republican Senator to Washington DC in over five decades. The spotlight was also on the race between NRA-endorsed Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and pro-gun control challenger Alison Grimes (D). McConnell won handily. NRA-endorsed Senatorial candidate Joni Ernst (R-IA) also won.

# News comment title:
Guns Were a Huge Part of My Life Growing Up. Should We Talk About Them Differently Now?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Here's what I submitted.

I have guns. At one time I kept them all loaded. Now I still have guns but none of them are loaded because we have grandkids and there is no telling when they might visit.

But when they do visit we talk about guns by breaking out the BB guns where I can teach them about guns and how to be safe with them. With no real danger. I also hunt with the two older grand sons.

My grandmother taught me how to be safe with guns and how to shoot them when I was eight years old. And the first thing she told me is guns kill. So you can never be careless with one. Not even once. Because it only takes a fraction of a second to pull that trigger whether you meant to or not and you can never take that fraction of a second back.

And I talk about guns the way I always have and teach the same lessons. But at the same time is I am speaking out everywhere I can trying to get people to understand we have now reached a point where we have more "gun rights" than we have gun sense and responsibility to go with them.

Which means what we really need to do is change the way we see guns. Not something romanticized. Not some equalizer. Not an extension of your penis. We need to get back to understanding guns as a tool. A lethal tool. And end the insane NRA propaganda that a gun is the answer to everything. And everyone should own one.

And actually I think people who were raised with guns and still have them may be the best people of all to talk to people about guns. We are actually the ones who know what the problem is.

# News comment title:
Guns Were a Huge Part of My Life Growing Up. Should We Talk About Them Differently Now?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Here's what I submitted.

I have guns. At one time I kept them all loaded. Now I still have guns but none of them are loaded because we have grandkids and there is no telling when they might visit.

But when they do visit we talk about guns by breaking out the BB guns where I can teach them about guns and how to be safe with them. With no real danger. I also hunt with the two older grand sons.

My grandmother taught me how to be safe with guns and how to shoot them when I was eight years old. And the first thing she told me is guns kill. So you can never be careless with one. Not even once. Because it only takes a fraction of a second to pull that trigger whether you meant to or not and you can never take that fraction of a second back.

And I talk about guns the way I always have and teach the same lessons. But at the same time is I am speaking out everywhere I can trying to get people to understand we have now reached a point where we have more "gun rights" than we have gun sense and responsibility to go with them.

Which means what we really need to do is change the way we see guns. Not something romanticized. Not some equalizer. Not an extension of your penis. We need to get back to understanding guns as a tool. A lethal tool. And end the insane NRA propaganda that a gun is the answer to everything. And everyone should own one.

And actually I think people who were raised with guns and still have them may be the best people of all to talk to people about guns. We are actually the ones who know what the problem is.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

Everything obeys gravity, and flows downwards.

# News comment title:
Some Suggestions for Weathering the Next Florence

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I live in Wilmington North Carolina.  I had no power for 5 days. I survived.

First things first.  The local beach communities do NOT want to force those million dollar homes from the beach front.  Why?  Because they pay a large amount in property taxes.  Any beach community that says otherwise if fooling themselves.

Second - the Federal Government now provides the flood insurance that used to be provided by private industry. Yes the program is Administered by private insurers but the risk is assumed by anyone paying taxes to the Federal Government.  So yes, that little old lady with a small farm in Indiana is supporting those wealthy enough to build those waterfront homes through her taxes.  Why is it that private insurance companies pulled out of the flood insurance  program?  After all, according to conservatives private industry does every thing BETTER than the Federal Government.  The answer is simple.  The insurance companies accepted global warming, along with the associated sea level rise, and decided that no  matter how high the premiums it posed too much risk for them, and their bottom line.  It wasn't a political decision, it wasn't a liberal CEO decision but it was clearly based on money.  so now their profits are guaranteed through the administrative fees imposed in applying the Flood Insurance Program for these homeowners.   This is a sham and a travesty and must stop.

Third - WE are stupid people. We think we can beat back Mother Nature.  Home designers tell beach front property owners that they can limit the damage from storms with walls on the bottom and first living floor that blow out when water comes through protecting the home from being totally washed away.

It is time.  Time admit that all the money in the world won't stop this devastation from happening.  Hard decisions have to be made. You want a beach front home?  You are on your own for insurance.  You want to ride out the storm?  Don't expect a rescue until the storm passes.  Towns have got to find other sources of revenue. 

That leaves river flooding.  Unfortunately, the same rules may have to apply based upon the topography of the land.

Its a tough subject, that's for sure

# News comment title:
I Told Her We Were Brought Over the Rio Grande on a Raft. I Never Called It a Smuggling.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I know a family here who slaved in LA cleaning, scrubbing other peoples toilets, floors, stairs working through the nights so it would shine that morning, but they never stopped dreaming of home here in Mexico, they made sure their kids learned solid values and received an education they never had, little by little they saved, scrimped and bought a corner place that would become a restaurant, years later 20 years...they put a downpayment on place next door a little hotel, they sparkle, the gringos congregate and hotel stays booked, the restaurant has a line in mornings, Freddy, the son runs it, very little turnover, people, young people aspire to work there, the best service in Vallarta, and Freddy? he donates to schools, bankrolls his workers education, for 20 years have patronized his restaurant, witnessed him paying for funerals, soccer and scholarships, they are among my favorite people here, always a big smile, the parents are stiff in old age, very modest and unassuming, most kind, am humbled they count me as not just breakfast patron, but friend of the family, sacrifice was the currency of their love of place and family they continue to nourish the people who work for them with respect, dignity, and help them achieve their dreams, they have a few cousins in LA still, but when his parents went up to visit at Christmas.... they were strip searched and held for a time in detention this sweet couple who toiled for decades there, they are frail now, it saddened me to hear this turn of events for you see family is everything and seeing the new baby meant so much to them, I don't have the answers, just this piece of a story from one family, and hope America finds it's heart, it's humanity, for it feels lost and am ashamed of us.

# News comment title:
There’s an Amazingly Simple, Beautiful Way to Fix Midwestern Farmlands

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Crop insurance replaces half your expenses, so instead of losing $200,000 you only lose $100,000. Family living expense is not replaced so you are in debt for that also. Every time you use the insurance you insurable yield is lowered by that amount. Fields are insured on individual plots, a poorly performing field may be uninsurable.


In my area the EPA already mandates how and how much fertilizer is applied. Farmers can no longer use liquid nitrogen and the dry fertilizer has to be applied in three separate stages instead of just two larger amounts. If more stringent control is warranted combines can be equipped with yield monitors and GPS so the poor performing areas can be mapped. Then crop insurance would be contingent on those areas being fallowed.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Sounds like a wonderful solution that would address multiple problems and would be self-funded to boot.

Unfortunately,  I doubt the lobby representing the fertilizer-manufacturing industry would let this go unchallenged...

I guess that's what progress means: plan for a better future, but know it won't ever arrive without a fight.

# News comment title:
No One Called the United States “America” Until It Became an Empire

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It was a surprise to read the notion that the use of the proper noun "America," as a synonym for "United States of America" was late in development. In less that two minutes I found "America" as a meaning the "United States" in the Federalist papers and in an 1818 letter of by John Adams. I would have searched for more examples but it seemed rather silly: America has been the common shorthand for the United States since its inception.  In the late 1970's  I first heard the idea that, somehow, the term should apply to all inhabitants of the Americas. This idea came from well-meaning  Americans with less than perfect understanding of how languages work and and even less understanding of the feelings of people of other nations. I would suggest due caution before walking into a working class bar in Toronto and loudly announcing that all the patrons are really Americans.
